thread.title: Women’s World Cup champions inspire next generation of girls
thread.title_full: Women’s World Cup champions inspire next generation of girls - MarketWatch

author: By     Jennifer Booton
title: Women’s World Cup champions inspire next generation of girls
text:
MarketWatch/Jennifer Booton Slide 1 of 13 Thousands of people gathered in downtown Manhattan on Friday to honor the U.S. women’s soccer team in a ticker-tape parade, the first to honor female athletes in more than 50 years.
The women’s team drew the particular interest of young girls. Several children were present that play on their own U.S. soccer teams, many hoping to one day follow in the footsteps of star players like Carli Lloyd and Abby Wambach.
Lloyd scored three goals in the first 16 minutes of the team’s championship game against Japan on Sunday. The team won its third World Cup title, defeating Japan 5-2.
“We got up at 5 a.m. to get down here,” said Kitty Falco, a mother from Syracuse, N.Y., who traveled to New York City with her family. “We are all huge fans.”
The parade began near Manhattan’s Battery Park, in the Canyon of Heroes, at 11 a.m.
MarketWatch/Jennifer Booton Slide 2 of 13 Kiera Ward and Melissa Schwartz pose with an American Flag draped over their shoulders after taking several pictures of the U.S. women’s soccer team before the championship team boarded a bus to downtown Manhattan just before the start of the ticker-day parade.
MarketWatch/Jennifer Booton Slide 3 of 13 Teenage girls Stephanie Blaskovic, Lindsey Wynne, Victoria Gianatiempo, Christina Lavelle, Diana Gorga and Kelly Grogan pose with American Flags in Times Square just before heading downtown to catch the ticker-tape parade. The girls said they love soccer and used to play on the same team together.
MarketWatch/Jennifer Booton Slide 4 of 13 Kitty Falco, a mother from Syracuse, N.Y., said she woke up at 5 a.m. to travel to New York City for the ticker-tape parade. “We are all huge fans,” she said.
MarketWatch/Jennifer Booton Slide 5 of 13 Five members of the L.I.F.E. Elite Soccer Club gather in Times Square to meet with the U.S. women’s soccer team ahead of the start of the parade. The team traveled to Canada to watch two of the World Cup games, including the U.S. 2-0 defeat against top-ranked Germany in Montreal on June 30. The young team played a game in their own league while in Canada.
MarketWatch/Jennifer Booton Slide 6 of 13 A group of mostly women and girls lift their cameras for photos as the U.S. women’s soccer team boards a bus to travel to Battery Park, the start of the ticker-tape parade, after an appearance on Good Morning America in Times Square.
MarketWatch/Jennifer Booton Slide 7 of 13 The Burns family from Monmouth County, N.J., pose with their signs after traveling an hour by bus into New York City to watch the parade. The children, Jack and Juliana, said they watched every U.S. women’s team World Cup game with parents Angela and Ray. Juliana’s favorite player is 35-year-old Abby Wambach, from Rochester, N.Y., while Jack said he likes Carli Lloyd.
MarketWatch/Jennifer Booton Slide 8 of 13 Dad and daughter duo Greg and Madison Johnson get ready to head to downtown Manhattan for the parade after scooping up breakfast near Times Square.
MarketWatch/Jennifer Booton Slide 9 of 13 Friends Megan Poenish and Kimi Duke pose in T-shirts of their favorite players: Alex Morgan and Abby Wambach.
MarketWatch/Jennifer Booton Slide 10 of 13 Couple Chris Gawin and Sarah Lobroth pose for a picture in Times Square.
Yvonne Dennis Slide 11 of 13 Young fans of the U.S. women's soccer team outside Good Morning America at Times Square early Friday morning.
Getty Images Slide 12 of 13 The U.S. women’s soccer team waves to fans as it travels up New York City’s Canyon of Heroes, shortly after at 11 a.m. The milestone parade is the first honoring female athletes in five decades.
